description.narrative: Spotlight Initiative Violence against women and children is one of the most widespread, persistent and devastating human rights violations in the world today.

participating-org.narrative: UGA Office of the Prime Mster

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
OUTCOME1 INDICATORS
1.2 Number of new and/or strengthened laws and/or policies on ending VAWG and/or gender equality and non-discrimination developed that are in line with Uganda' commitments at regional and international levels on human rights standards and respond to the right respond to the rights of women and girls, particularly vulnerable women and girls INDICATORS FOR OUTCOME 2
2.1 Existence of a functioning national and/or sub-national coordination and oversight mechanisms at the highest level for addressing VAWG/VAC/HP and promoting SRHR, that includes representation from marginalized groups 2.2 Percentage of national budget being allocated to the prevention and elimination of all forms of VAWG/HP, by sector
2.1.1 Number of relevant MDAs and DLGs that develop strategies, plans and/or programmes to prevent and respond to VAWG, including SGBV/HP and promote women and girls’ SRHR, including for vulnerable women and girls.
2.1.5 Number of targeted national and sub-national training institutions for public servants that have integrated gender equality and VAWG, including SGBV/HP and the promotion of women and girls’ SRHR in their curriculum, as per international standards (pre and in-service)
2.2.1 There exists a national multi-stakeholder coordination mechanism established and/or strengthened composed of relevant stakeholders, with a clear mandate and governance structure and with annual work plans
2.3.3 No. of key government officials with greater knowledge, capacities and tools on gender-responsive budgeting to end VAWG, including SGBV/HP, and to promote women and girls’ SRHR
3.2.7 Number of women and girls benefitting from skilling and livelihood opportunities, by type
3.3.2. No. of relevant non-state institutions (media and work places) that have been supported to develop and/or strengthened strategies/policies on ending VAWG, including SGBV/HP and promoting gender-equitable norms, attitudes and behaviours and women and girls’ rights, including

comment.narrative: 1.2 10 laws in place that response to ending VAWG, gender equality and non discrimination 2.1. One coordination mechanism- The GBV Reference Group 2.2 No baseline 2.1. 0 MDAs with strategies to address GBV interventions 2.1.5 No training institutions have integrated VAWG/HP and SRHR in their curriculum 2.2.1. 0 multi sector coordination mechanism. 1 GBV reference group in place however it it is not a multi sectoral and national in nature. No baseline data 3.2.7 0 Women and girls with skills and livelihood opportunities in Spotlight Districts 3.3.2 0 non state institutions supported to develop strategies, policies on ending VAWG 4.1.4 No baseline on government service providers with capacity to deliver quality 8survivor services 4.2.1 no baseline on number of GBV survivors with increased knowledge and access to quality survivor services

1.2.1 Advocacy for the passing of at-least 2 bills conducted (legal aid bill, Human Rights Enforcement Bill and Administration of Justice Bill)
.2.1. Convene 1 high level multisectoral dialogue on mainstreaming GBV in government programmed
2.2 Hold stakeholder engagements to influence the integration of VAWG/HP response in NDP Programme Implementation Action Plans
2.1 . i) 4 MDAs and 6 DLGs have developed strategies for response to VAWG, HP and SRHR in plans and budgets
2.1 ii) 12 MDAs and 6 District Local Governments trained and mentored to mainstream VAWG, HP and SRHR in plans and budgets
2.1.5 Develop curricular for 4 pre and in service training institutions to integrate VAW/VAC/HP and integrated SRHR training
2.2.1 Support Ministry of Gender Coordination of GBV interventions
2.2.3 Over 100 Government Officials trained in gender responsive budgeting to end WAG/HP and SRHR
3.2.7 i) Support 20 women groups (100 women) with livelihood and economic empowerment programs to promote reduction in violence against women and girls.
3.2.7 ii) Support formation and formalisation of 60 women led mining groups
T 3.3.2 14 companies identified and trained on gender seal certification Mechanism for recognition of excellence of private sector, CSOs, Local Governments for integrating GBV
T 4.1.4 Train legal aid service providers on (i) VAW/VAC/HP and SRHR, (ii) early identification of incidents ,on mandate in prevention and response, (iv) referring mechanisms, and (v) use of alternative dispute resolution guidelines.
Conduct mentoring for police, prosecutors, magistrates, and probation and social welfare officers, as well as legal representation and psychosocial support to survivors using the IJM Collaborative Case Management model
4.2.1 Support at least 200 GBV survivors have increase knowledge and access to quality essential Services

1.2.1 2 Multi media advocacy campaigns for the passing of the legal aid bill conducted by LASPNET. 2.1 One (1) High level meeting and one national stakeholders’ meem convened to review the coordination mechanisms 2.2 3 NDP3 Programme Implementation Action Plans have mainstreamed VAWG/Response ie the Human Capital Programme; 2.1.1. 4 MDAs (Ministry of Gender, Ministry of Public Service, Ministry of Local government have developed strategies for GBV response. These include revision of inspection manual to mainstream GBV response; review of accountability mechanism performance management systems/tools in public service; initiate coordination of VAWG 127 staff on 12 MDAs and 6 DLG staff have been trained and mentored on integration of GBV in plans and budgets. 2.1.5 Draft curricular for 4 preservice training institutions in place. Pretest of the curricular and TOT training has been conducted. UNDP supported a Joint initiative to build capacity of JLOS institutions in GBV response (UNDP/UNWomen and UNICEF) 2.2.1 Ministry of Gender was supported to convene the GBV response Committee was supported to convene national meetings and implementation plan developed 2.2.3 160 government officials in 6 District Local Governments and 12 MDAs have been trained and mentorship is ongoing on mainstreaming GBV response in plans and budgets. 3.2.7 Over 383 F and 13m supported trained and supported and provided agro inputs to start livelihood initiatives 2 in 22 groups including rice, groundnuts, mushrooms cassava farming and vegetable growing and poultry, piggery and goat rearing and also value addition. These were 16 groups of 232(224F:8M) iin Tororo, and 6 groups 164(159F:5M) in Kampala. 39 women mining groups were trained on formalization processes and equipped with entrepreneurial knowledge and skills, business development and financial management skills to operate successful business and prevent/respond to VAWG and SGBV/HP 14 companies were identified and enrolled in the Gender Equity Seal Certification programme. The Guideline and checklist drafted for recognition of excellence of institutions that mainstream GBV in their programmes 4.1.4 44 officials were trained and identified as TOTs in investigation, prosecution, adjudication, and trauma-informed care in response to cases of GBV and VAC. These included officials from the Ministry of Gender, Labour and Social Development (MGLSD), Uganda Police Force (UPF), the Office of the Directorate of Public Prosecutions (ODPP), and the Judiciary. 4.2.1 No result yet attained

1.2. One law reviewed for approval and 2 bills passed into law
2.1. Convene 1 high level multisectoral dialogue on mainstreaming GBV in government programmed
2.2 No target for 2020
2.1 .1 A Training and capacity needs Assessment study of 20 MDAs and 6 District Local Government to integrate VAWG in the plans and budgets. 1 Ministry (Ministry of Local Government to review Inspection tool to integrate VAWG/SRHR indicators.
.2.1.5 A Review of the curricular for 4 pre and in service training institutions to integrate VAW/VAC/HP and integrated SRHR training
2.2.1 No target for 2019.
2.2.3 40 officials from Ministry of Local Government trained on prevention and response to SRHR/VAWG/VAC/SRHR and integrate it in local government inspections.
3.2.7 No target
3.3.2 1 non state institution supported to facilitate private sector companies to implement policies and practices to end Gender Based Violence
4.1.4 Train 200 legal aid service providers on (i) VAW/VAC/HP and SRHR, (ii) early identification of incidents ,on mandate in prevention and response, (iv) referring mechanisms, and (v) use of alternative dispute resolution guidelines.
4.2.1 Support atleast 200 GBV survivors have increase knowledge and access to quality essential Services

1.2.1 2 Key Bills have been passed into Law such as the Human Rights Enforcement Act and Administration of Judiciary Act. These were as a result of key advocacy and review efforts done by Uganda Human Rights Commission and Legal Aid Service Providers Network (LASPNET) that started in 2019. The legal laid laws was reviewed and submitted to Parliament for approval.
2.1 1 No dialogue convened . However, a review of the existing coordination mechanism was done as part of the Capacity assessment study.
2.1.1. No MDAs have initiative programmes to respond to VAWG/HP and SRHR. As progress, 20 MDAs and 6 DLGs were assessed on their capacities and training needs to to mainstream VAWG/HP and SRHR in their plans and budgets
R 2.1.5 Review report for 4 preservice training institutions in place. Pretest of the curricular and TOT training has been conducted.
R 2.2.1 No result for 2020 R 2.2.3 30 officials from Ministry of Local Government trained on the role of local governments in how to prevent, respond and mainstream SRHR/VAWG/VAC/HTCPs;, in local government inspections and delivery of services.
R 3.2.7 No result 1 Institution , Private Sector Foundation Uganda was supported to carry training for companies to integrate GBV response in policies and practices.
A curricular for TOT on workplace initiatives to prevent and respond to GBV was finalized
217 participants were trained on Formulation and Enactment and enforcement of Human Rights Based Compliant Ordinance/by-laws to eliminate VAWG/HP AND SRHR”. This would lead to increased respect, protection and promotion of human rights of the most vulnerable persons in society, specifically aiming to eliminating all harmful practices such as child and forced marriages.
A gap analysis household survey of capacities of justice service providers in 11 sub-counties and 34 parishes in Kasese district was conducted to assess the communitys knowledge of VAWG/HP and essential service delivery.

2.1 one functioning national and/or sub-national coordination and oversight mechanisms at the highest level in place for addressing VAWG/VAC/HP and promoting SRHR, that includes representation from marginalized groups 2.2Increase budget being allocated to the prevention and elimination of all forms of VAWG/HP, by sector 2.1.1 4 MDAs and 6 DLGs have strategies, plans and/or programmes to prevent and respond to VAWG, including SGBV/HP and promote women and girls’ SRHR, including for vulnerable women and girls. 2.1.5 4 targeted national and sub-national training institutions for public servants that have integrated gender equality and VAWG, including SGBV/HP and the promotion of women and girls’ SRHR in their curriculum, as per international standards (pre and in-service) 2.2.1 One national multi-stakeholder coordination mechanism established and/or strengthened composed of relevant stakeholders, with a clear mandate and governance structure and with annual work plans 2.3.3 Key government officials in 6 Spotlight Districts and 11 MDAs with greater knowledge, capacities and tools on gender-responsive budgeting to end VAWG, including SGBV/HP, and to promote women and girls’ SRHR

2.1 One national GBV high level coordination platform in place at Ministry of Gender; one national GBV/Covid coordination platform established. Ministry of Gender coordinated and conducted 2 high-level dialogues with Government officials and Parliament on increasing response and financing GBV in plans and budgets. 2 policy briefs developed on GBV financing and GBV and on GBV/Covid response. . The National GBV/VAC Multi-Sectoral COVID-19 Response Plan (2021-2024) developed 2.2 : %age allocation is not yet assessed. However 3 NDP3 Government PIAPS have specific and costed interventions on GBV included. i.e community development, Community mobilization; Human Capital Development. 6 Districts have 49 costed interventions for GBV prevention and response financed in district Budget Framework Papers and Development Plans 2.1 .1 4 MDAs and 6 DLGs have strategies for response to VAWG, HP and SRHR .6 DLGs have costed strategies in DDPs . (MoPS with curricular & reviewed accountability and performance mechanism: MoLG with revised inspection manual; Ministry of Gender with National Covid response strategy; checklist and guideline; PSFU with TOT curricular and Gender Quality Seal programme 2.1.5 4 pre and in service training institutions with revised curricular that has been adopted to integrate VAW/VAC/HP and SRHR training. The institutions are in the process of customizing these courses. These are Civil Service College of Uganda, Nsamizi Institute of social Development, Law Development Centre and Uganda Management Institute. An online course on GBV mainstreaming in plans and budgets has been developed and civil Service College and a multi media centre established to support online capacity building for government officials. 2.2.1 One partner coordination mechanism established by Ministry of Gender and coordination meetings held. A GBV dashboard developed to facilitate monitoring and coordination of GBV response interventions by partners at national and Local Government Level. 2.2.3 179 government officials in 6 District Local Governments and 127 MDA with capacity mainstreaming GBV response in plans and budgets. A pool of 10 GVB government experts established and facilitated to conduct GBV trainings for government officials and selected officials from 5 cities
